results.title: In the name of the father [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Jim Sheridan, Gabriel Byrne and Hell's Kitchen
results.brief_description: Gerry Conlon, a petty crook in Belfast during the 1970’s, gets in trouble with the IRA. His father sends him to England where a twist of fate puts him in the wrong place at the wrong time when a pub in Guildford is bombed. Gerry and three of his friends, although innocent, are charged and convicted. Gerry’s father joins him in prison and despite years of a strained relationship, Gerry learns to regard his father’s gentle spirit as a strength. Enlisting the aid of a lawyer, Guiseppe Conlon is determined to prove his son’s innocence, and when he dies in prison, Gerry is determined to take up the cause. Evidence is discovered which implicates senior police officials in a massive cover-up, and the ‘Guildford Four’ are finally set free. Daniel Day-Lewis, Pete Postlethwaite and Emma Thompson are brilliant in their roles.

results.title: Down by law [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: Jim Jarmusch, Alan Kleinberg, Black Snake and Grokenberger
results.brief_description: It is a sad and beautiful world that provides the setting for Jim Jarmusch’s third feature. It seems like a world of bad luck and trouble to Jack and Zack. These deadbeats may well have deserved a comeuppance, but not jail, certainly not for the long haul, and absolutely not in the same cell together. The big-talking, foolish Jack and the sullen, daydreaming Zack are mutually repellent. A new convict is pushed into their cell, an Italian tourist, Roberto. Somehow the three manage to escape and they wind up in the trackless bayou, pursued by bloodhounds. Cast includes Tom Waits, John Lurie, Roberto Benigni and Ellen Barkin.

results.title: Colonel Redl = Oberst Redl [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Istvan Szabo, Film Und Fersehen, Mafilm Sudio Objectiv, Mokep, Osterreichischer Rundfunk-Fernsehen and Zweites Deutsches Fernsehen
results.brief_description: Alfred Redl is one of the most infamous and ambitious figures of modern European history. The son of a poor railway worker, he “invented” the story of his life to gain acceptance to the ranks of the aristocracy and to climb to the pinnacle of the Austro-Hungarian military regime. As head of military intelligence during the last days of the corrupt Austro-Hungarian Empire, he committed suicide amid accusations of spying for the Russians, treason and homosexuality. More interested in the political and emotional texture of the story than in its historical verisimilitude, this film unmasks a strong, charismatic man made vulnerable by his hunger for success and barely masked insecurities that provides the film’s riveting subject matter. Klaus Maria Brandauer’s impersonation of Redl is chilling and disturbing. Nominated for an Oscar for best foreign film, winner of the Jury prize at the Cannes Film Festival, this film is a dazzling drama of power and intrigue.

results.title: Mephisto [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Istvan Szabo, Manfred Durniok and Ma Film
results.brief_description: Based on the novel by Klaus Mann, “Mephisto” is the story of one man’s struggle between his art and his morality. Set in Germany of the 1930s, “Mephisto” plots the rise of provincial actor Hendrik Hoefgen (Klaus Maria Brandauer) and the simultaneous rise of Nazism in Europe. Hoefgan is a talented, if vain actor who is not above flattery and manipulation of those around him to achieve his ambitious ends. A man who once had left wing political leanings, Hoefgen is forced to renounce his personal politics and even betray former colleagues in order to gain favour with the Nazis and advance his career. “Mephisto” is a compelling portrait of an artist whose ambition is in conflict with his integrity. The mood and aesthetics of 1930s Berlin are aptly evoked in this award winning drama (Oscar for Best Foreign Film, 1982). Directed by Istran Durnoik (Sunshine, Meeting Venus) and also starring Krystyna Janda and Ildiko Bansagi.

results.title: Bitter moon = Lunes de fiel
results.creator_credit: Roman Polanski, Canal+, Les Films Alain Sarde, R P Productions and Timothy Burrill Productions
results.brief_description: This dark-humored comedy drama explores perverse sexual obsession in a marriage based on mutual hatred. While on a luxury cruise to Istanbul a repressed English couple, Nigel and Fiona, (played by Hugh Grant and Kristin Scott-Thomas) meet a crippled American writer and his beautiful French wife. As the American entertains Nigel with elaborate accounts of the sexual power games he and his wife play (related in lengthy flashbacks), the English couple’s curiosity is aroused. Gradually they become drawn into their twisted and ultimately destructive relationship as unwitting observers and participants in a tragedy with the most extraordinary outcome. Cast also includes Peter Coyote and Emmanuelle Seigner.

results.title: Flying elephants
results.creator_credit: Fred J. Butler, Hal Roach and Kodak Cinegraph
results.brief_description: Set in the Stone Age when men were forced to marry and then work on the rock pile - that’s why it was called the “Stone Age!”. King Ferdinand has ordered that all men between the ages of 13 and 95 must be married within 21 days or be executed or banished for life, or both. Amongst those vying for a wife are the big husky caveman known as the Mighty Giant (Oliver Hardy) and his rival, Twinkle Star (Stan Laurel).

results.title: Kiss me deadly
results.brief_description: A chance encounter leading to, what is referred to in the film as, the search for ‘the great whatsit’, follows the conventional investigative structure of the private eye film. However, the bravura visual style, the array of characterisation and the aural fabric of allusion and metaphor add meaning to this basic structure, marking the film as the climax of the initial noir cycle. The private eye, Mike Hammer, is portrayed as a fascistic anti-hero ultimately caught between big crime and big government. Aldrich and Bezzerides consciously denounce Spillane’s sleazy creation injecting in its place an atmosphere of cold war hysteria, an implicit critique of the ‘end justifies the means’ mentality.

results.title: Triple trouble
results.creator_credit: Charles Chaplin, Leo White and Essanay Film Manufacturing Company
results.brief_description: A slapstick comedy starring Charlie Chaplin as a screwball kitchenhand who unwittingly foils Colonel W. Nutt’s scientific research and in the process involves everyone around him in a search for local train robbers. Also stars: Billy Armstrong, Albert Austin, Henry Bergman, Bud Jamison, James J. Kelley, ‘Snub’ Pollard, Edna Purviance, Wesley Ruggles and Leo White.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Charles Chaplin, Leo White and Essanay Film Manufacturing Company

results.title: Last resort [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: Pawel Pawlikowski, Ruth Caleb and BBC Film Unit
results.brief_description: The low key Last Resort is an offbeat love story set around a defunct British seaside holiday resort. Russian immigrant Tanya (Dina Korzun) arrives at Gatwick airport with her ten year old son Artiom (Artiom Strelinikov) to be reunited with her British fiance. When he doesn’t arrive the distressed Tanya rashly decides to claim political asylum in order to stay in the country. She is then taken to a refuge holding center situated in an abandoned holiday resort where she virtually becomes a prisoner. While detained she meets amusement arcade manager Alfie (Paddy Considine) an ex-crim who takes Tanya and her son under his wings. Soon enough an unlikely romance develops between the pair. Director Pawel Pawlikowski handles his material delicately eliciting some wonderful naturalistic performances from his leads. While cinematographer Ryszard Lenczewski adds to the melancholy nature of the film by giving the look of the once thriving fun park an eerie beauty. Cast includes Lindsey Honey, Dave Bean, Katie Drinkwater. Pawel Pawlikowski: Winner of the 2001 BAFTA award for the Most Promising Newcomer in British Film.

results.title: The Killing of Sister George [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: Robert Aldrich, Associates and Aldrich Company and Palomar Pictures
results.brief_description: The erosion of a longtime lesbian affair between a television star (Beryl Reid) who plays the role of “Sister George” the bleeding heart heroine on a British TV soap opera and her younger lover (Susannah York). The breakup of the relationship comes about when a broadcast executive who fancies the younger woman, decides to write Reid out of her key TV role. The basic thrust of the plot is the gradual development of a rapport and sympathy with Reid, in inverse ratio to the loss of respect for York. The film received an X rating on its release due to a controversial five-minute lesbian love scene. Director Robert Aldrich achieved the look and feel of a “Made in Britain” picture, although most of it was shot near downtown LA. Cast also includes Carol Browne, Ronald Fraser, Patricia Medina and Hugh Paddick. Screenplay by Lukas Heller from the play by Frank Marcus.
